results.title: Relatives (AFC)
results.creator_credit: Archer Films, Quantum Films, Henri Safran, Basil Appleby and Antony J. Bowman
results.brief_description: Set in beautiful cattle farming country New South Wales during the 1980s, this quirky comedy drama centres around a family reunion to celebrate grandfather’s 80th birthday. Spanning three generations, the relatives all gather at the historical family homestead, some from the city and others from the country. Add to this an intruder from Czechoslovakia, lots of alcohol, family jealousies and rivalries, “dangerous” liaisons, a somewhat bewildered and bemused grandfather, and an important announcement which will affect the whole family, there can be only one outcome - disaster. Cast includes Bill Kerr, Rowena Wallace, Carol Raye, Ray Barrett and Norman Kaye. Music written and played by Norman Kaye and photography by Tom Cowan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Archer Films, Quantum Films, Henri Safran, Basil Appleby and Antony J. Bowman

results.title: Relative strangers
results.brief_description:
Simon thought he knew his parents… A film about a family, a deception and its legacy.
The visual effects in this film were all camera-created, using a technique of projection onto a moving sheet to create the insubstantial and constantly changing images that reflect the perceptions of the narrator (Simon Cooper). Nothing in his world turned out to be what it first seemed.

results.title: Relative strangers
results.brief_description: Family ties are often a fragile thing, as Simon is about to discover as he unravels the secrets of one man’s childhood. A haunting look at the issues facing modern family life.

results.title: Relative strangers
results.brief_description: A beautiful mediation on the meaning of family and blood ties. Photographs and home movies of the past form the extent of one man’s childhood memory of his father. In attempting to recover his past, he discovers that time’s absences and betrayals are apt to be repeated.

results.title: Relationships and stress (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: David A. Tapper, Time-Life Video & Television and Tapper Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Coping with Serious Illness”.
One part of a series of six programs which looks at the major problems faced by Joan Robinson, who is dying of cancer. This episode shows ways of handling the changing relationships with family, friends and medical personnel. Experts talk to the viewer about how serious illness can materially change relationships and how people can cope with the emotions and strains that inevitably follow diagnosis of a serious illness. Narrated by Meryl Streep.

results.title: Relationships
results.brief_description: Starting, ending and maintaining relationships is never easy. Peter Quarry leads couples through the minefield and discusses: What attracts people to each other, how to turn a friendship into something deeper, how to keep a relationship alive, conflict, resolution, knowing when to quit, being single and enjoying it.

results.title: Rekindled rivalry
results.brief_description:
Hepburn Springs and Daylesford are setting to meet on field for the first time since 1945, after many years playing in separate leagues. Rivalry comes to the forefront for both players and communities.

Thank you to Rob Rodini, Shane Robertson, Luke Adams. Television news excerpt reproduced with kind permission of WIN TV, Ballarat.

TRANSCRIPT

It’s all right; the time has finally arrived for Hepburn and Daylesford to go head to head. With both sides once again back in the same footy league, locals can’t wait for the big clash.

Oh well, they don’t have a lot going for them down there in Hepburn. They’re always a poor man’s version of Daylesford but we should be right….Come on there…

Been around the Club, I suppose, from when I was…I don’t know…from when they could carry me to the ground. I’ve been connected with Hepburn ever since, and I don’t know, the rivalry was there before my time, it was always…I think every town that is close has the rivalry in the footy sides. When they put the sewage line down through Hepburn, well there were people in Daylesford said “Oh great, we been waiting years to shit on Hepburn”. Well I suppose if you want to call that rivalry.

I think it’s always been there. Even when I was at Daylesford I must admit that I poached some Hepburn players, Hepburn Football Club’s poached Daylesford players. That tends to set a bit of rivalry off the field in a sense that while there having a beer together they’re actually sledging each other, an it’s got to a stage where the rivalry’s rebuilt but in a stronger situation because of ,uh, playing in the same league and the closeness of the towns.

The only thing that probably eats at me a little bit about Hepburn is I don’t think they give our footy club enough respect, you know. A few things in the paper this week they’ve said and you just see that there’s not much respect there and it does eat at you a little bit, but I’ve go no doubt, with my boys, the only way you’re goin’ ta get respect off a club like that is to have the win on the board Saturday afternoon. So that’s what we’re setting out to do.

Player game calls.

Don’t want Winda’s controlin…kick behind play…James Newton was paddling here, get back with him.

…you have to hit the target when you come back in the middle…the ball in the middle of the ground went sideways again to no one really aright…50 meter penalty…

Player game calls

You must do the job…you must do the job…OK…I don’t want to see you ten metres off the contest…we must hit it hard…

Siren

Cheers, whistles…sing…Red white and blue…should old acquaintance be forgot.

results.title: Reinventing Japan
results.creator_credit: Alex Gibney, Teleac Holland, KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.), Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Jigsaw Productions and PBI Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Pacific century”.
This program looks at the peculiar relationship between Japan and the United States that emerged in the wake of World War II. Set to the tunes of big band jazz and including footage of the period never before seen, “Reinventing Japan” captures the spirit of a strange era, full of idealism and democracy as well as bitter betrayals, when one country tried to reinvent another in its image - with surprising and unexpected results.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alex Gibney, Teleac Holland, KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.), Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Jigsaw Productions and PBI Productions
